The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including the following: proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures; evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation; notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs; and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, BASF has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Program is updated as necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities.  The Emergency Response Program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in these changes.  The overall Emergency Response Program is coordinated with the Jefferson County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. BASF has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., Port Arthur fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, BASF conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP) EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The RMP rule requires that this site provide an executive summary in the RMPlan.  This summary provides the following items:
-Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies
-Description of the stationary source and regulated substances handled
-Worst case and alternative release scenarios
-General accident release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
-Five year accident history
-Emergency response program
-Planned changes to improve safety
 
 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
 BASF Corporation has a long-standing commitment to public safety.  This commitment is evident by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as employee training and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement controls to prevent potential releases of hazardous chemicals.  However, if a release does occur, our well-trained personnel will respond to mitigate the release. 
 
 DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED
 BASF FINA Petrochemicals complex is a joint venture between the BASF Corporation and ATOFINA Chemicals.  SABINA Petrochemicals is a joint venture between the BASF Corporation, ATOFINA Petrochemicals, and Shell Chemical. This complex is operated by BASF and is located in Port Arthur, TX adjacent to the ATOFINA Refinery.  The sites steam cracker receives naptha feed from the adjacent Atofina refinery.  This feed is used to produce ethylene, propylene, benzene, and toluene.  Approximately two-thirds of the feed-stock processed in the Sabina Petrochemicals LLC facility will come from Shell, and one ¿third will come from the BASF FINA Petrochemicals naptha steam cracker.  The feed processed in the Sabina Petrochemicals LLC are used to produce propylene a

nd butadiene.  
 
 The complex uses/produces the following chemicals that appear on the EPA regulated chemicals list, and have been identified as having the potential to cause significant off site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:
 
 Toxics: None
 
 Flammables:  Hydrogen, Methane, Acetylene, n-Butane, Ethylene, Propane, Propylene, Ethane, 2-Butene-trans, 1-Butene, Isobutene, 2-Butene-cis, Butene, Isobutane, 2-Butene, Hydrogen, Isopentane, Pentane, 1,3-Butadiene, Propyne, 1-Pentene, Propadiene, 1,3-Pentadiene, 1,2-Pentadiene, 2-Pentene (E), 2-Pentene (Z), 3-Pentene, Vinylacetylene, 1-Butyne
 
 HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS
 There are no toxic chemicals stored or used within the complex, which are above the inventory threshold limits as defined by the EPA. Therefore, BASF has no worst case (WCS) or alternate release scenario (ARS) identified for toxic chemicals in this Risk Management Plan. 

 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
 The following is a summary of the General Accidental Release Prevention Program in place at BASF. Because processes at the plant regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the Accidental Release Prevention Program. 
 
 PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
 BASF maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to ensure safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific departments within the complex are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date Process Safety Information. Process Safety Information reference documents are readily available, as required by the Employee Participation element of PSM. 
 
 Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS¿) provide

chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations.  In addition, safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, and composition) have been documented in the unit.  Operation teams verify the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and automated shutdown systems. 
 
 BASF also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This documentation includes equipment information such as, materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical ratings, etc.  In combination with written procedures and trained personnel, this information provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes via Management of Change (MOC), to confirm that safety features in the process are not compromised. 
 
 PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS
 BASF has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled prior to the design phase. Each process is systematically examined during this process to identify hazards and verify that adequate controls and safeguards are in place to manage and/or mitigate these hazards. 
 
 BASF primarily uses the HAZard and OPerability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform process hazard analysis. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the premier systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and process experience as well as engineering expertise. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process.  Action items are assigned to prevent and mitigate any hazards identified when the team believes such measures are necessary.  BASF uses this method to ensure the design is as intrinsical

ly safe as possible. 
 
 All PHA action items are forwarded to engineering and process safety management for resolution. Mitigation and prevention options are implemented in response to PHA findings by the engineering and management teams. All mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until completion. The resolution of each finding is documented and retained. 
 
 Provisions are in place for the updating and revalidating of the PHA results to confirm that process controls and/or hazards have not deviated significantly from the original design safety features.  Periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.
 
 OPERATING PROCEDURES
 BASF maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as  (1) commissioning/first time startup, (2) unit startup, (3) normal operations, (4) temporary operations, (5) emergency shutdown, and (6) normal shutdown.  These procedures can be used as a reference by Process Technicians and provide a basis for consistent training of new Process Technicians.  These procedures are regularly reviewed and certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes via the Management of Change (MOC) process.
 
 BASF also maintain Process Safety Information that provides guidance on how to respond to upper or lower limits that exceed specific process or equipment parameters. Written operating procedures along with this Process Safety Information provides Process Technicians in the process unit the means necessary to safely perform their job tasks.
 
 TRAINING
 In order to ensure compliance to written procedures for process operations, BASF has implemented a thorough training program for all employees involved in an operating process.  All new employees receive basi

c training in plant operations in addition to job specific training. After successfully completing this training, a new Process Technician is paired with a qualified Process Technician to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After Process Technicians demonstrate necessary skills and prove that they have adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe and efficient manner, they will be certified to work independently.  All Process Technicians periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to confirm their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. All of this training is documented for each Process Technician, including the method used to verify that the operator understood the training.
 
 MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
 BASF has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) developing written procedures, (2) conducting training, (3) performing preventative maintenance (PM) inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. These activities together form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of all process equipment.
 
 Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) a process overview, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) Emergency Response Plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to ensure they can perform their job in a safe manner.  Written maintenance procedures confirm work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Equipment are inspected and tested to verify the intended function, and to verify that equipment operates within acceptable limits. Employees will correct any identified deficiency before placing the equipment back into service.  If the replacement/repair is not a r

eplacement-in-kind, Management of Change (MOC) will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to verify the safe operation of the equipment.
 
 Quality assurance is another integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program. BASF incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. All equipment is inspected to ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use.
 
 MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE (MOC)
 BASF has a comprehensive system to manage change. The MOC procedure applies to the installation of, and/or modifications to equipment, facilities, procedures, chemicals, and technology. Changes are reviewed by operations management to (1) verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. All affected chemical hazard information, process-operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  All personnel are trained on applicable procedural changes.
 
 PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSRs)
 BASF conducts a PSSR for any new facility or modification to the existing facility that requires a change in the process safety information.  A PSSR is conducted prior to startup to ensure that: (1) all equipment is installed per design, (2) all procedures are updated to reflect changes, (3) all affected employees are trained on the new procedures, (4) and a PHA was performed and all action items are closed or that the change was handled under the MOC program. The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. In addition, a PSSR requires field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function.
 
 COMPLIANCE AUDITS
 BASF periodically conducts compliance audits that include the following: internal PSM and RMP audits; safework, hotwork, and confined space permit audits, and periodic general EHS audits performed by Corporate Safety.  Typical a

udit teams are comprised of different disciplines, including Process Technicians and management personnel.  Audit findings are formalized and presented to management for resolution.  All audit finding corrective actions are tracked until resolution.  All audits are retained for at least five years.
 
 INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
 BASF promptly investigates all incidents, or near misses that reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to perform a root cause analysis and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to management for resolution.  Corrective actions are tracked until these items have been resolved.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees and contractors affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years to allow these reports to be available for review during future PHA¿s and PHA re-validations.
 
 EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
 BASF management encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention. Employee participation can include, but is not limited to, (1) updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information, (2) Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR¿s), (3) employee safety observation program, (4) participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation team, (5) in addition to a number of other teams to promote both process safety and personal safety.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in Employee Participation Element of PSM is documented in the PSM/RMP manual.  The various safety teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including opera

tions, maintenance, electrical/instrumentation, engineering, and plant management. 
 
 SAFE WORK PRACTICES
 BASF has long-standing history of safe work practices to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, such as contractors, (2) a Lock/Tag/Try  Procedure to verify isolation of potential energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) procedures for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to confirm adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. In addition to these ¿non-standard¿ work activities, BASF also permits all routine and non-routine maintenance work.  These procedures, along with training of all personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed in a safe manner.
 
 CONTRACTORS
 BASF uses contractors as part of its regular on site work force in addition to periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Contractors work on or near process equipment therefore, the plant has procedures in place to verify that contractors  (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills to perform the task, (3) are aware of the hazards in their work area, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, (6) and inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This will be accomplished by providing contractors with a general Process Overview and information about site safety and health hazards.  In addition, all contractors are trained on the Emergency Response Plan requirements and safe work practices prior to their issuance of a permit to work. BASF evaluates and places priority on contractor safety programs and performance

during the selection of a contractor.  Plant personnel monitor contractor performance to help ensure that contractors are abiding by their safety obligations. Contractors participate in regular facility emergency drills.
 
 RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS
 The processes at BASF have hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation. In order to prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors BASF has put several safety systems in place to help: contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, and mitigate the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used throughout the facility:
 
 
 Release Detection
-Gas Detectors (%LEL) with Alarms
- Benzene Detectors
- Hydrogen Sulfide Detectors
- Ammonia Detectors
 Release Containment/Control
 All process relief valves discharge to the flare/thermal oxidizer
 Automated Shutdown Systems for specific process parameters
 Redundant equipment and instrumentation
 Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) for process control instrumentation
 Atmospheric Relief Devices
 Structural/Equipment Fire Proofing
 Relief Valve Maintenance Procedures
 
 RELEASE MITIGATION
 FM200 - Fire Suppression and Extinguishing Systems
 Deluge System for specific equipment
 Trained On-site Emergency Response Personnel
 Personal Protective Equipment
- Flame Retardant Clothing
- Chemical Protective Clothing
- Self Contained Breathing Apparatus
- Turnout Gear for Firefighting
Steam Curtains to Disperse Vapor Release
Emergency Isolation Valves
Employee Evacuation System
Fire and Gas Alarm Panel 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
This is a new facility and therefore has no accident history.
